data.title: Fill in the blank in the Array, CenterContainer and Dictionary class reference
Need apply_angular_impulse
data.body:
I think a `RigidBody` should have both **mass** and **moment**.
Also, they need `apply_angular_impulse` to change angular velocity based on their moment.

data.title: An option to batch-delete all references to various asset files if needed.
data.body:
The reason for this request is that sometimes when exporting, you may end up seeing new .tex files created everywhere. The result of this is a much higher file size for the full project and a lot of duplication. I know for some cases, you may want to just have the material created with the surface itself, but considering that I always use the override material, the surface material just gets in the way and works to clutter my project file system.

The solution for that (and any other case where you want to do a complete deletion of an asset quickly and without breaking everything), would be an option to auto-delete all references to the asset in question when you get the warning prompt that comes with the _delete_ option.

For instance, in deleting an excess .tex file for instance, it would delete the references to it within all materials that use it while not deleting the materials themselves (so a diffuse texture slot for example would be reset to _null_). The project will still work when playing it and opening scene files, but the extra textures and any other old cruft can then just be cleaned out quickly and easily (with no visible impact in this case at least since said materials were overridden anyway and those materials use .tex files in a folder specifically created for them).

Comments?

data.title: Creating directories broke!
data.body:
Creating directories broke!
I discovered that someone had broken a very good thing that worked perfectly before.

Earlier I commonly when saving new files, simply specify a desired path, and if it did not exist, then all the required directory created automatically to any depth and saves the file with the specified name. like this... in 1.1 stable

```
func seve_file():
    FILE_PATH = "res://SAVED_DATA/new_NONEXISTENT_directory/test/test.txt"
    FILE = File.new()

    if (FILE.file_exists(FILE_PATH) == false && VOX_FILE.is_open() == false):
        FILE.open(FILE_PATH, File.WRITE)
        FILE.store_string("string_12345678")
        FILE.close()
```

but now when I tried to save a file in a directory that previously did not exist, I was suddenly was refused and I had to rewrite the old code which previously worked fine using a single string, and create a whole monster which added all a bunch of blocks in which it was necessary to rewrite each directory selected call options to create the directory manually, and this shit for automation ...
in 2.0.1 stable

```
func seve_file():
    var dir = Directory.new()
    dir.make_dir("res://SAVED_DATA/new_NONEXISTENT_directory")
    dir.make_dir("res://SAVED_DATA/new_NONEXISTENT_directory/test")

    FILE_PATH = "res://SAVED_DATA/new_NONEXISTENT_directory/test/test.txt"
    FILE = File.new()

    if (FILE.file_exists(FILE_PATH) == false && VOX_FILE.is_open() == false):
        FILE.open(FILE_PATH, File.WRITE)
        FILE.store_string("string_12345678")
        FILE.close()
```

simply return how it worked before, it was perfect!!!

data.title: Can't access preloaded script member from static function with single line call
data.body:
Tested in Windows 7 64 bits, Godot 2.0.2

It is not possible to access a constant from another script under **certain conditions**.
It makes me unable to separate inner classes from a giant script in my project, unless I pass the constant as argument everywhere.

**Steps to reproduce**
scene1
1) Create a script A on a node
2) Create a script B with a constant in it
3) In script A, use the constant from B. The code editor will complain.
4) Run the scene: it works anyways.

scene2
1) Create a script A on a node
2) Add a constant in A
3) Create a script B with a static function using the constant of A
4) Call the function of B from A. The editor will complain.
5) Run the scene: it won't run, the same eror will happen.

**Example project**: http://zylannprods.fr/dl/godot/ConstError.zip
As attachment: [ConstError.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/238879/ConstError.zip)

In the linked project, there are two scenes.
In scene1, the code editor raises an error while the script is being written, but the scene runs without problems. Only one preload() is evaluated.

In scene 2, the scene doesn't runs and raises the same error.
Here, there are two preload() to evaluate successively.

**Theory**
I didn't see the C++ code, but I think that when GDScript sees preload(), it will try to compile the referenced script, but if that script has itself a reference to the other script, it will fail because the other script has not finished to compile.
It's interesting to note that on the other hand, static function calls will work because they might be looked up at runtime instead of compile-time.

Maybe related: issue #1411

data.title: Reopening a script doesn't updates it from disk
data.body:
Tested on Windows 7 64 bits, Godot 2.0.2

For convenience, I had to switch to Sublime Text for editing a script to benefit from rectangular selection. I saved, then reopened the script in Godot, but the changes where not there.
I opened from another editor, my changes were applied. Godot didn't actually reloaded the file.

If I keep the script open, it will update as soon as I unfocus/refocus Godot. This issue happens when the script has been closed.

Steps to reproduce:
1) Create a script and attach it to a node
2) Open the script in the script editor, then close it (Ctrl+W)
3) Modify the script in an external editor and save it
4) Reopen the script in Godot: notice nothing has changed

From 4), the only way to get an update is to unfocus and refocus Godot by clicking somewhere else (desktop on another app).

data.title: Camera2D jiggling with Rotating mode
data.body:
Win7 64bit, Godot 2.0.1-stable

When a Camera2D (with Rotating option enabled) is inside of a quickly rotating object some jiggling is visible.

**Steps to reproduce:**
- Create a new scene
- Create a hierarchy:

> [Node2D] main
> 
> > [Node2D] RotatingObj
> > 
> > > [Polygon2D or any other visible Node2D] Obj
> > > [Camera2D]
> > 
> > [AnimationPlayer]
- Enable Rotating option in the camera
- Add an animation, autoplay, looped, create a keyframe for RotatingObj rotation 0 degrees at second 0, and a keyframe for rotation 360 at second 1 (so the object does a full circle in a second)
- Play the scene

The object will jiggle visibly.
This is probably due to the nature of the engine. Probably hard to fix, but thought it's a good idea to place it here :)

This occured on a low-end laptop. Might not be as noticable on desktops.

data.title: RigidBody physics for TileMaps (CollisionShape passing to parent)
data.body:
_feature proposal_
I was thinking about a kind of game, where you sort of build a ship - rooms, corridors, wings etc. The best way to do this would be with TileMaps. But there is an obvious problem.

To fly this ship you would have to treat it as a RigidBody, and there is no option like that. There is an option "Use Kinematic", but it's really confusing. Can I move() the TileMap ? How can I detect collisions with it?

The workaround right now would be to contain the TileMap in a RigidBody and for each cell create a collision shape suitable for a tile in that cell. The fact that it's doable this way, and not via a "TileMap" option is not a good thing in my opinion.

The whole idea of collisions within TileMaps seems a little flawed to me. My proposition:
1. Change "Use Kinematic" to "Use Static Body" selected by default
2. TileSets can contain collision shapes, but don't have to contain Static Body anymore
3. If the user deselects Use Static Body the TileMap will now have to be a child of a PhysicsBody2D (Rigid,Kinematic or Static) which will use the collision shapes

Since the tilemap can be very big I can understand why this was never a feature in the first place, but since an aformentioned workaround is possible... This would also make TileSet creation a little less of a pain (no need to use static bodies).
What do you think? Is this feature a good idea? Would it be hard to implement?

**Steps to reproduce:**
Open Task Manager, put your mouse over any menu element, and wait a bit until the tooltip show up.

_Really unnecessary to fix, but maybe you find another problem related to what is causing this, so I decided to relate anyways._

data.title: Anim tree: add filters on Animation nodes
data.body:
I wasn't going to push this upstream, but I think it's a first step towards some of the things that @slapin wants.  You don't want to be merging filter dictionaries per wire per frame, so it should really be implemented as filters on Animation nodes which are then semi-statically updated from the rest of the tree.

And it's a straight addition which doesn't affect the existing filtering options, so it should be fairly harmless.

data.title: Better bounding box select in 3D
data.body:
**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Awesome feature of Select Mode (Q) is that it can do bounding box selection, helps with selecting multiple or small objects, but it doesn't work if there are other objects behind object we want to select.
It then selects that "behind object" and because current nature of this tool automatically transforms it to the movement of the mouse, so there is no way to use bounding box selection in most scenes.

I would suggest to separate selection from multi transform tool and make it more like ON/OFF mode for transform gizmos. It would also help if user wants, for example, only translate objects that he selects, or only select object without seeing any transform widgets on the screen that can stand in the way sometimes.
I can elaborate that idea (visual help what I have in mind?) if that's not enough.

data.title: Lock object for 3D
data.body:
**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
In 2D there is an option to Lock objects from selection, something like that would be useful for 3D as well.
